quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: I was pretty sure that I'll just make a lot less, but I'll enjoy what I'm doing. But now I am making more in compensation that I made at Uber. And the difference is that now my compensation, my earnings, keep going up as long as the newsletter is growing, so there's no theoretical cap on this.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: I decided I liked being a manager, but I did not like how I was not in charge and I couldn't take corporate telling us to do stuff. So I decided for next job, I could be doing this, but instead I'd like to be in charge. So I'd like to be a founder or someone who's high up, so that I can actually take full responsibility.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: I was thinking to myself, so hold on. I would go off and do this for like ten years, because that's how much you need to plan to do it. I need to stop doing what I'm doing right now. And then I want to do it again. So it's reminding me of the story of this fisherman.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: One big learning for me from newsletters is if you put in ways that you have to do certain things, put in constraints for the things that you need to do, and then you're going to do that. Without that, when you're on your own, when you're an entrepreneur, I found myself upset at myself for not just wasting my day.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: Almost 15 years of being this star employee who really wants to do well, I found myself upset at myself for not just wasting my day. But I fixed it by telling people, 'You're going to get this every week,' and now I have to do it. I just have no choice.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: One of the biggest, best things about doing what we do when you're in charge of your time is, you can double down on pulls. I just felt this pull, of this huge interest of people caring about this. So I didn't have much else to do, so I was able to double down.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: There's three simple steps. One, write a blog post. Two, do this three times a week. Three, do it for two years. And I guarantee, if you do this, you're going to be famous. The more I read it, the more I thought he actually means something with it.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: One is habit of depth in the field, whatever field you do. Become an expert somewhere, somehow, before you start, because you'll be a lot more credible. I think there's no shortage of reporters and journalists who don't know about stuff, but they can interview people, but that doesn't give anything extra.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: I see this as a business, and I'm trying to put on that business hat. I'm building a one-person business. I want to make it sustainable, I want to make it successful, and I find that this thinking really helps me detach as well. I can actually enjoy my weekends as opposed to thinking, 'I need to write this.'

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: If you're going to be a really well known person on YouTube, you might get more people watching you, but you'll have a lot more competition. For me, writing, especially with software engineers, it's really efficient, because I can scan through it. I don't like YouTube videos, especially for learning about stuff, because I can't even scan through the whole thing.

quotes.speaker: Gergely Orosz
quotes.text: I told myself that I'll do this for six months, and I'll see what happens. If there's traction, it's great. I might have found myself a new job, basically. If not, I'll just refund people. It's basically like a startup. So I told her and my family that it's going to be a lot of work and I might not be around as much.

takeaways: Leaving a high-paying tech job to write a newsletter can be financially viable if you have deep expertise and years of writing practice behind you
Self-imposed constraints and public commitments are essential for productivity when you work for yourself - telling people what you will deliver forces you to deliver
The best way to build a successful newsletter is years of consistent writing before you monetize, following Jeff Atwood's advice of writing regularly for two years
When you notice strong pull from an audience toward something you created, double down on it immediately rather than sticking to your original plan
Building depth and credibility in a specific field before starting a newsletter is more important than any growth tactic - genuine expertise creates lasting value

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the conventional startup path by choosing to skip the VC-funded startup entirely when he realized the end goal was what he was already doing
Argues that writing is a superior medium to video for education, going against the trend of everyone moving to YouTube and TikTok
